I use a Trezor hardware wallet to store keys for most of my bitcoin and ether holdings. You can access the bitcoin holdings using Trezor’s official wallet software found at _________________________. You can access the ether holdings by using mycrypto.com software. I use a passphrase, which is an additional security measure, for the cryptoassets stored here.

To access the funds you’ll need my passphrase, which you can find stored at _______________________ (do not include the address), my PIN (stored ___________) and the device itself. If you can’t find the device or the PIN, you can also access the funds by using the wallet backup seed stored _____________________________________ [do not include exact address] and my passphrase, using the “restore” function to put the keys onto another Trezor device or software wallet. If you need to use this restore functionality you’ll probably need help.

My Hot Wallets

I use the Coinomi application on my phone to store small amounts of bitcoin, ether, ether classic, and monero. In order to access these assets you’ll need my phone PIN (stored ____________) and the PIN for my app (stored _________________). If you can’t access my phone, my wallet backup seed is stored ________________________________ [do not include the exact address]. With the wallet backup, you can use a restore function to recreate this wallet on another device. If you need to do this you’ll probably need help.

Transferring Ownership of the Assets to You

In order to liquidate these assets you’ll need to go through an exchange. It may be helpful to use __________________________ exchange, where I already have an account. In order to transfer these assets to others without liquidating them, each person must set up their own account or cold storage device to receive the assets. This is not something that can be done, in aggregate, by an executor, trustee, or third party for important security reasons. I would prefer ________________________________ {you hold the assets, you liquidate the assets, you hold half and liquidate half, you do whatever you want to with the assets}.

This document is intended to supplement my will and allow these assets to pass either through the intestacy statutes or through a will or trust that has been previously set up.

{Say something nice in closing to your loved ones}

This letter was last updated on {insert today’s date}. Signed: __________________________________ {your name}

More complex planning

If you have implemented multisignature, shamir’s secret sharing, or some other multi-share key system, you definitely need to mention that in the letter. If you’re using a passphrase with your hardware wallet, you definitely need to mention that in the letter too. While these topics are beyond the scope of this chapter, I’ve written extensively on those systems and on smart contract inheritance planning in my book and on my website.

Storing your letter

After you’ve finished writing your letter, save it in a safe place. If you have a trusted confidant, consider telling them the letter exists. Don’t give them a copy yet. If you have a lawyer, you could discuss the letter with them too.

Congratulations!

You’ve taken one huge step to protect your loved ones. I wish you all the best in your crypto journey.

Jenny Q. Ta is a veteran Wall Street, former CEO of Titan Securities, and co-founder of VCNetwork.co, who discovered bitcoin in 2016. She’s now a self-made millionaire. Follow her journey at: Instagram.com/JennyQTa

Bitcoin Inheritance

The year was 2016. The place, a Las Vegas blockchain convention. Their eyes locked.

There she stood, at one of the booths where they were giving away brochures about bitcoin, tentatively reading one brochure after another. You see, earlier that year she'd received a tax refund of about $500 and used it to buy bitcoin. It seemed like a good idea because she’d heard so much about bitcoin and the Winklevoss twins.

She had watched The Social Network a few years prior and had felt the twins weren't too bright in their handling of the Facebook dilemma. But she knew they would be on to that next big thing, so she jumped in blindly and just tried to learn along the way.

Some people don’t believe in magic, but he knew. It was love at first sight.

She looked over her right shoulder to find a tall man in his mid-twenties standing there. His hazel eyes sparkled. He said his name was Jake.

She politely replied her name was Amber, then returned to reading the brochure. She was hungry for information about this new form of electronic cash that can be sent without a central bank or any intermediaries. She was fascinated by the idea of a peer-to-peer network. Bitcoin’s decentralization felt unique.

"Yes, that was how I fell in love with bitcoin too," he said, gesturing toward the brochures.

"Oh? How long ago?" she replied.

"Just three years ago when I bought my first one at 1000% less than today," he boasted. She rolled her eyes.

"So you got in at $50?"

"Indeed, you did the math pretty quick. You’re skilled,” he said.

"That's a beautiful thing to say," she smiled.

"Not as beautiful as what I'm looking at right now," he answered.

By Christmas 2016 their knowledge of bitcoin had grown as fast as their whirlwind romance. She was a quiet, introverted yet articulate woman. He was opinionated and extroverted. They were complete opposites, so of course they fell hard. They were inseparable.

They were both orphans, in a way. Amber had no family of her own. Both her parents were dead and her extended family left her at an orphanage. As for Jake, he'd run away from home as a teen and wasn't looking back. The bitcoin community became their chosen family. Choice was as key to the custody of this asset as it was to their romance. This would be the life they choose, together. Bitcoin was that North Star to guide them to wealth, hope, and financial freedom they never would have dreamed of.

Through booms and busts their relationship deepened. They'd since combined both of their bitcoin holdings in cold storage, an offline wallet that takes the form of a small hardware device. They couldn’t afford much bitcoin, so they pooled their resources to buy a third coin for a future fund. Maybe it would become a savings fund for their future child.

By October 2017, bitcoin had nearly hit $5,000 and their wealth rose faster than they'd ever thought possible. With just the few hundred dollars they'd originally invested, it would have been laughable to invest in real estate or any of the stocks on Wall Street.

Life was good, so they celebrated their one-year anniversary in Sin City, where they first met. She was in her first trimester, carrying their first child. So instead of sinning too much, they went and danced their hearts out at one of the nation’s biggest country music festivals, the Route 91 Harvest Festival.

That day, in 2017, a gunman took 58 lives, including Jake’s, who threw his own body in the way to shield her from a storm of bullets.

After the funeral, where she showered his cold cheeks in tears, Amber learned she didn’t legally have rights to access any of his accounts because they weren’t married. The only inheritance left for their son would be the joint wallet, a self-custodied asset. She left their old apartment and moved on to raise their child somewhere that didn’t constantly remind her of the love she’d lost.

These days, their son Jake Jr. is starting to crawl. Amber teaches him to say "dada" while showing him a picture of Jake. She continues to study bitcoin in order to safeguard that nest egg Jake left behind.

And sometimes, when no one else is around, she still holds their hardware wallet with three precious bitcoins close to her mouth then whispers his name. It is the key engraved inside her chest.

Samantha Radocchia is a software engineer and entrepreneur, founder of the blockchain startup Chronicled, who was named to the 2017 Forbes “30 Under 30” list for enterprise technology. She often lectures and guides educational programs, from colleges such as California’s Singularity University, to political institutions like the United Nations. In her free time, she’s made over 700 jumps as a competitive skydiver.

The following essay is an excerpt from her book, Bitcoin Pizza: The No-Bullshit Guide to Blockchain.

Bitcoin's Cultural History

A brief history of the bitcoin movement

Bitcoin’s countercultural beginnings may not be anarchistic, per se.

However, the impulse toward decentralization and disintermediating such intermediaries as the government and other large institutions was crucial to crypto’s origins. The thesis that blockchain is the operating system of the future is an expression of what I feel is a very real and ongoing paradigm shift that is still in its early stages. The shift has many different facets: from centralized to decentralized, opaque to transparent and trusted, siloed to connected, and regulated to self-enforcing. These shifts from the current to a new paradigm could all be called countercultural in the broadest sense. I might go so far as to say this paradigm shift is “extracultural” or “supercultural,” since we’re transcending our current operating system and leveling up.

We tend to think of the term “counterculture” in sixties or seventies terms—the hippies and Vietnam protests—but the term has greater applicability. Most of our cultural systems, whether they be financial, governmental, communications, or agricultural, are highly centralized. The “extracultural” systems we’re now building are networked and peer-to-peer, bypassing and even eliminating the center.

Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies are also extracultural in asserting, for instance, that we don’t need banks and shouldn’t trust them. We shouldn’t have to pay a fee or have a wire transfer take five days to send money across borders, perhaps to family members in other countries. This stance challenges our deeply entrenched existing global systems and the current rules of the global economy. Some of this may be paranoid, and many bitcoin maximalists are libertarian by nature. NYU professor Nouriel Roubini’s critique is in part an assertion that cryptos are wacky, right-wing gun toters and that the crypto world is just nuts.

In my opinion, some of crypto’s values do, in fact, arise from an attempt to assure self-preservation, self-sovereignty, and privacy. However, crypto’s underlying values are not solely self-centered, but also involve networks of individuals and everyone’s right to participate in this global ecosystem.

This is in part a response to the 2008 financial crisis, which I bring up again because it truly is important to crypto and blockchain, but tends to be ignored or forgotten in current discussions of the technology. Trust banks and other financial institutions? They’re the ones who came up with all these new-fangled derivatives, such as credit-default swaps and other complex financial products, which turned out to have no real foundation—talk about mythology!—and led to the mortgage crisis and the falling of the dominoes. Trust government? It was the government that bailed out the financial institutions that created the financial crisis, because they were “too big to fail,” while leaving individuals, not too big to fail, in the lurch. Of course, a reasonable argument might be made that government intervention was necessary to staunch further collapse. Satoshi Nakamoto, however, came up with an alternative proposal.

The year 2008 was the proverbial perfect storm. Everyone began feeling uneasy about both the American and world economies. Would a global financial collapse ensue, and, if so, what would it look like? On the other hand, many financial advisors still say, “That’s ridiculous. That’s never going to happen. This is like a doomsday conspiracy theory.” Saying something’s a “conspiracy theory” is a time-honored way of dismissing it by calling it crazy. What this dismissal doesn’t recognize is that crypto and blockchain are a social movement as well as a technology, and powerful social movements have a tendency to shift paradigms in often unpredictable ways. This is how history is made, so it’s important to focus on history. Certain moments in time give rise to new ideas, and ideas, like religions, can and do change history. They shift our perception, our ways of seeing and acting in the world.

The shift isn’t a simplistic one from pro-government and pro-regulation to anti-government and anti-regulation. Many crypto fundamentalists support government, or at least regulatory, scrutiny. However, a possibly complementary perspective is developing based on the realizations that (1) a nation-state is in many ways defined only by borders drawn on a map; (2) a corporation is just a legal definition; and (3) fiat currency is ultimately backed by military prowess and nuclear bombs. There is also the clear recognition that many national governments are unstable and subject to sudden power shifts, making the attempt to create disintermediated, extra-governmental peer-to-peer networks anything but crazy.

In fact, they’re more sensible than many of the institutions that persist in our current globalized context. The Soviet Union fell apart just recently, historically speaking. The Ottoman Empire, which had been in existence for seven hundred years, finally collapsed in 1922, less than a hundred years ago. The fallout continues in both cases. European colonial states, such as the United Kingdom and France, drew lines on paper dividing the landmass of the Ottoman Empire into such states as Syria, Iraq, and Iran. Ongoing instability among ethnic and cultural groups, and over access to vital resources such as oil, resulted and has continued in the region up to the present day.

The breakup of the Soviet Union has had similar consequences. While history itself is quite complicated, these examples point to the tension that results from the rise and fall of governments. The response—especially given that we live in an age where digital technology is transforming the world—is, in the case of crypto, an attempt to create a means of exchange whose value transcends geo-political structures and boundaries. The motivating impulse is to provide a sense of security, particularly in places where political and financial insecurity have become the norm. Cryptocurrency isn’t anti-government in a frighteningly nihilistic way, as some have asserted. It’s based on a real examination of a real question: can we still trust current civil structures? They’ve worked, more or less, relatively well for quite some time.

However, given that the global economy is transforming, can these historical structures still be relied upon? Ongoing crises such as those in the Greek and Venezuelan economies, as well as the Great Recession of 2008, would seem to give substance and credence to cryptocurrency’s original mission of establishing financial power and security through peer-to-peer networks and, by extension, the people who make up those networks. This is happening on a number of different fronts and scales. Many current crypto projects, which get little play in the American press, focus on “mesh networking,” devices that enable bitcoin and other cryptocurrency transactions to take place where there is no or little access to cell phone service or internet service providers.

The focus here is remote rural areas, such as in Colombia, whose inhabitants are already becoming well versed in this approach. Much of this is based on extremely localized small-scale communication. Then, there’s the much larger scale we usually focus on when considering cryptocurrency. A globally useful digital currency must be transacted internationally. The corresponding ethos is countercultural, not so much in a political sense, but because it runs counter to the centralization of internet service providers and cellular data networks entirely controlled and managed by huge communications corporations. Such centralization limits access and bandwidth and enables these corporations to charge exorbitant subscription and other fees.

Speaking of large corporations such as banks, there is tremendous controversy over Ripple, the company behind the cryptocurrency XRP. The conflict again focuses on centralization versus decentralization. A large portion of the crypto community dislikes Ripple because Ripple Labs has entered into partnerships with international banks and other institutions that intend to use its tokens to facilitate financial exchanges. Also, Ripple Labs, according to its critics, created and profited from Ripple’s token, XRP, by means of centralization. Blockchain fundamentalists see Ripple tokens and the company that created them as a way to both make use of and subvert decentralizing blockchain technology in the service of centralization and intermediation. This controversy can neither be fully explored nor resolved here. Both sides offer impassioned arguments. There is a lot of misapprehension and bickering, which is hardly a new phenomenon.

At one point, President Trump offered his opinion that since China controls bitcoin—because of the one-time Chinese near-monopoly on proof-of-work mining—Ripple was a preferable alternative: “Hate bitcoin; love Ripple.” One size does not fit all. The controversy stems from the fact that crypto and blockchain technology can be used to meet different needs in different circumstances. If the goal is to empower people in unstable financial and political communities, some degree of centralization is clearly needed. If the goal is to uphold the existing financial system more efficiently—well, that runs counter to cryptocurrency’s initial purposes and tendencies. Given the speed of technological change, there’s no doubt that large, powerful existing institutions are intent on retrofitting: using blockchain technology to make current processes faster and more efficient.

No one, including crypto fundamentalists, is naïve enough to expect the powers that be to say, “Okay, cool, we’re just going to give up everything and everyone that benefits from the existing system and move to a decentralized world.” Intermediaries make a lot of money. Banks and whole-sale distributors in supply chains—the middlemen—are often the most profitable institutions in the systems they facilitate.

Again, the overarching principle of Bitcoin is decentralization. In my opinion, where blockchain and cryptocurrency technologies are being utilized to promote centralization, they are no longer blockchain or crypto in any meaningful sense of the terms.

Some way, somehow, a transition or bridge from the existing system to a new one will need to be built. While they may have a countercultural element, effective crypto and blockchain technologies can’t be completely countercultural, ignoring the current context and starting from scratch. There is an existing system that needs to be considered and adjusted in the migration to less centralized processes.

As long as we’re on the subject of conflicting cultures, just who are these crypto people anyway? There are the:

• Maximalists, who believe bitcoin is the use case for blockchain
• HODLers, long-game investors “Holding On for Dear Life” through volatile markets
• OG (“original gangster”) traders in the game from the beginning, who have seen at least three bitcoin bubbles: a drop from $31 back down to about $2 in 2011; a high of $1,242 in 2013 descending to a low of about $200 in 2015; and a precipitous descent from a top of $19,783.06 in 2017 that took place in only a month
• Institutional traders
• Developers and designers, working not just to HODL but also build • ICO scammers, who raise millions from unsuspecting retail investors
• Trolls who post memes and negative comments on Twitter
• Shills promoting a certain coin or company, usually also on Twitter
• No-coiners (critics like economist Nouriel Roubini)
• InfoSec (information security and cybersecurity) techies
• “Crypto bros” who resemble tech bros and finance bros • Ethereum community as a whole, quite eclectic in itself, whose members can often be seen at conferences with rainbows and unicorns on their T-shirts
• Bot armies
• Thought leaders, journalists, podcasters, newsletter writers

And that’s only just the beginning. There’s no way to do a “typical user profile,” as these people are anything but typical. There are tons of archetypes in the community, but generalization is dangerous, although impossible to avoid.

Although there are many types of bitcoiners, the larger cultural and lifestyle observation is that many crypto community members are both biohackers and computer hackers. They tend to question everything, especially received wisdom from centralized organizations, such as the FDA. Perhaps, they suggest, a conspiracy is involved, with the FDA touting grains simply because they are the mainstay of big agriculture. The question “Do you eat keto?” appears frequently in communications among crypto fundamentalists.

Originally, Reddit boards were the community’s most common communications medium. Now it’s Twitter.

Above all, the blockchain and crypto community is rich: rich in its culture, diverse in its participants, a constantly evolving, living ecosystem. Like many communities of practice, there are common member archetypes and mediums of exchange. There are different clans, values, and belief systems. Different eating habits and clothing styles. There is no single individual, ecosystem, or myth that can define it all.

Along with the myth of Satoshi Nakamoto, which tipped the domino that created this global social movement, Bitcoin Pizza Day represents the tipping point where a seemingly innocuous bitcoin-for-Pizza exchange became a bridge from the techie ambiguity of zeros and ones to the current culture.

On May 22, 2010, programmer Laszlo Hanyecz made the first purchase of real-world goods with bitcoin: two Papa John’s pizzas. He structured the deal with a fellow member of the BitcoinTalk forum, the online meeting place for bitcoin originalists. He paid ten thousand bitcoin in exchange for the US dollars he bought the two pizzas with. Bitcoin was worth only a few pennies apiece at the time, so the value of the transaction was twenty-five dollars for a total of sixteen slices. It was the first real-world bitcoin transaction... Now the community celebrates May 22 as Bitcoin Pizza Day. My favorite holiday, by far...

Both myth and history function to promote power-sustaining ideologies by naturalizing, universalizing, and rendering them self-evident and inevitable. Myth, in its utter ambiguity and refusal to lay claim to truth, creates the illusion of reality. We are in a unique moment in human history where we are working together to shape not only new technologies, but new, binding myths.

We, as bitcoiners, are finally looking beyond the myths that shaped our past and that we took to be self-evident—myths like centralization, opacity, and silos—to get our first glimpse into a world that may have been there all along and will start defining our new reality.

Janey Gak is a security consultant who discovered bitcoin while working with displaced people in Afghanistan. She believes bitcoin may be a catalyst that fixes many of the economic and development issues found in poorer and more corrupt countries. In her free time, she researches Islamic finance, economics, and how bitcoin can be introduced around the world. The following excerpt is from her blog post “Knowing Your Coin Privacy (Using KYCP.org).”

How to Know Your Coin Privacy

Know Your Coin Privacy (KYCP) is an online tool for bitcoin users to visualize the degree of privacy in a bitcoin transaction. Various quantification metrics are used, including measuring the resistance of a transaction against privacy attacks such as Merged Inputs Heuristics and CoinJoin Sudoku. These metrics make the tool especially useful for determining the quality of joint transactions such as CoinJoins.

In other words: you can inspect the entire history of your wallet using a single UTXO (unspent output data from bitcoin transactions).

How to use the KYCP online tool

Note: KYCP relies on OXT for data. If you are unable to see your transaction analyzed, you must wait until at least six blockchain confirmations have been performed on the transaction. Find a transaction to analyze. In the example below, a transaction hash is used but a UTXO can also be provided. Input this value into the search bar at https://kycp.org.


Click to access the above example transaction in KYCP.org: f39d831aef2e49e21f542e2e3a2b0d577dae40132b7da49506b45e0b042794a7 (link)

Reading the results on KYCP

In the above example KYCP returns the following information, starting from the top:


1. How long ago the transaction was made. Three hours ago or at 2019–07–25 07:33:51.

2. A link to open the transaction in OXT.me.

3. The total value of the transaction: 14.6317 ฿.

4. How many addresses have been previously used in the transaction: 6 addresses reused. (More details on this later.)

5. How many inputs share a common previous transaction: 46 input merges and 0 output merges. For mix transactions, this number should always be zero. (More details on this later.)

6. Boltzmann support message: “OXT has not yet fully analysed this transaction. Please try again later for full results.” Because the example transaction is relatively large, Boltzmann data is unavailable. Most smaller transactions will otherwise display the Boltzmann info including deterministic links, possible combinations, and entropy.

Understanding address reuses

An address is considered reused if it has sent or received more than one input and one output. One input and one output (1–1) is a normal transaction however, anything more is problematic. The above example has six address reuses which means six of the addresses have been previously used in a transaction before.

Furthermore, there are 46 input merges. This means that of the 81 inputs, 46 share a common previous transaction. Thus it can be assumed they belong to the same wallet or collaborate together. Having no merges is ideal for privacy.

Understanding the graph


Left side: inputs. These two pink addresses share a common previous transaction.

The left side of the graph depicts all the transaction inputs including the address (note the color), a colored box (either orange, green, or red—more about this in the next section), a left bracket arrow (<), bitcoin amount, and input index.


The right column of the graph displays outputs. Some transactions may have labels such as “ANON_” or wallet names here. These are automatically imported from OXT.me.

In this example, there are 81 total inputs. Of these 81 inputs, 46 inputs share a common, color coded, previous transaction. Observe that index 2 and index 3 are both pink, for example. In total this address (6c8df...2d3) appears four times in the transaction.

Clicking on the left bracket (<) will open a link to the previous transaction in KYCP.org. Notice that the links for both index 2 and 3 are the same transaction.

Understanding clusters

The center column visualizes clustered inputs and outputs that have been regrouped as being part of the same entity or owner (this could be the same exchange, or individual wallet, and so forth). As mentioned in the previous section, there is a color box depicted next to an address in the input list. This color maps to the color of the bands shown here. An orange band indicates being identified in the same cluster. For merged inputs, this denotes coming from the same transaction while for merged outputs, it means they were spent by the same transaction. A red band indicates a relation between the two clusters, or in other words, address reuse.

Green bands, on the other hand, display a lack of any deterministic links. An example chart can be found in the next section.


In the above example, observe input 22 and 36. Looking at the TXIDS for 22 and 36 in the left column, one can observe these are indeed the same previous transaction (c5896…dc0), listed in light green. This means the two inputs originate from the same transaction. In this example we can see the two inputs mixed together previously.


In the following example, observe that inputs 1, 53, 71, and 74 are red, indicating address reuse. Looking at their addresses in the left column one can observe these are indeed the same address (bc1qg…2du), listed in cyan. This means these two clusters belong to the same wallet.


Although output 97 is not spent yet, it will bring its problematic history with it once it is spent.


Address bc1qt…azv on the list of inputs

Observe input 55 in the list of inputs. This same address is used in output 97.


Address bc1qt…azv also on the list of outputs

Example graphs


A CoinJoin using Samourai Whirlpool: https://www.kycp.org/#/b8593dad70162185d070f86e00a208d334411114f749629869a8d6ffe9162087/in

In the above CoinJoin, the Boltzmann information is returned whereas in the previous example of the large transaction it was not. Since this is a small transaction the system can easily return its analysis.


The above CoinJoin transaction has five inputs, each with an equal amount of inputs (.05 ฿). There are no deterministic links, meaning that the probability of a link between an input to an output is zero. This is considered good privacy.

Transaction (TX) efficiency compares transaction entropy to the “best possible transaction” with the same number of inputs and outputs. One hundred percent is considered good privacy. In Information Theory, entropy is the measure of uncertainty for a variable, while density measures the concentration of a substance. In the context of address analysis, a higher concentration of entropy is desirable, not less.

Lastly, the following is an example of what the vast majority of bitcoin transactions look like.


Update: New features

Recently, two additional features have been added to KYCP: entropy density and probable links.


Entropy density was introduced to compliment the obtained percentage of possible entropy known as wallet efficiency (labeled simply as “efficiency” in KYCP). Wallet efficiency is calculated by taking the actual entropy of the transaction and dividing it by the theoretical perfect score that could be obtained for that particular transaction configuration.

However, a drawback of wallet efficiency is that it is often so low (below 1%) that it can be impractical. Entropy density, on the other hand, is how the obtained entropy is spread across all inputs and outputs.


Entropy density has been calculated by taking the entropy* and dividing it by the total number of inputs and outputs. For CoinJoins, an entropy density of 1.0 or above is the target to shoot for. Conversely, an entropy density less than 1.0 denotes a suboptimal CoinJoin.


A suboptimal CoinJoin with an entropy density calculated at 0.988 (undesirable).


A Samourai STONEWALL transaction with a 43% wallet efficiency and an entropy density score of 0.264.

The above transaction utilizes the free STONEWALL feature of Samourai Wallet. STONEWALL creates doubt as to whether or not a transaction involves one wallet or two wallets. The entropy density score is high for a non-perfect CoinJoin as is the wallet efficiency, which can also be considered high for any kind of transaction. The 1.585 entropy score is the standard score for a STONEWALL transaction of a composition of 2 inputs and 4 outputs.


Whirlpool CoinJoins structurally obtain 100% wallet efficiency (100% of the maximum possible entropy for their composition) and always score above 1.0 entropy density. The first screenshot in the “Example Graphs” section is an example of a Whirlpool CoinJoin. *Raw entropy can be seen by clicking the OXT button and consulting the data provided in the ‘Summary’ tab. Note, however, that entropy is only provided for transactions within a certain limit of number of inputs and outputs.

Note: All perfect CoinJoins (CoinJoin that have the same number of inputs and outputs with all output values being equal) from 3 inputs and 3 outputs or higher will always return an entropy density greater than 1.0. Any CoinJoin less than 1.0 is considered suboptimal. Therefore, particular attention to entropy density should be paid when performing a CoinJoin and even more so when the entropy is less than 100%.

Sarah Jamie Lewis is a privacy researcher whose work focuses on consent, metadata resistance, and decentralization. She discovered bitcoin in 2010 and started using it in 2013. She’s the executive director of the Canadian nonprofit Open Privacy, funded for several years through cryptocurrency donations, with the vast majority being bitcoin. The following includes some of the best troll tweets ever posted in Bitcoin Twitter, roasting the stereotypical tech salesmen.

CurseChain Tweet Storm

Witches regularly cast curses without thoroughly documenting the conditions for lifting them, as such generations might (unwittingly) suffer under a curse originally intended for just one person. With that in mind I present CurseChain ($CURSE), audited curses on the blockchain.

Now I know what you are thinking: "Sarah, I can't see all the forest witches giving up their traditional methods to switch to Solidity", and I agree, which is why we are developing a new lisp-oriented smart-curses language.

"But what about cursed items" I hear you ask? And to that I answer "Supply-chain management.”

We are also announcing a new sybil-resistance mechanism: PoC: Proof of Coven. Before having curses accepted by the CurseChain you will need to sign off from one of the TrustedCovens™.

But what about the investors and incentives? Introducing CurseCoins! CurseCoins are tokens that can be used to nullify curses on the chain. Each curse has an associated CurseCoin value, and coins sent to a curse go directly to the casting witch.

"But what about scale Sarah? Is it infinite?" Yes. CurseChain has off-chain sharding: curses can be removed from the chain and turned into shards for the purposes of dealing with people who ask questions about infinite scaling.

"What about the privacy of my curses?" Introducing: CurseMix - a mixnet for CurseChain - targets can learn they were cursed but the witch behind it will be protected by the anonymity set of the mixnet.

CurseChain will be launching a testnet "when the hurlyburly's done", if you would like to contribute to development & security reviews, you should probably just donate to @OpenPriv.

I have had many great questions about CurseChain, so I'm going to answer them in this thread.

First up: Do curses stack & can you time delay curses? Curses do stack. One can be under an unlimited number of curses at any given time. Curses effects can be time delayed using CheckLockTimeVerify.

How do we mitigate a 51% attack? CurseChain blocks are produced by TrustedCovens™ and as such one must corrupt 2/3 of them to disrupt consensus. What happens when the CurseChain forks? Curses get doubled. We feel this is the best incentive.

Doesn't CurseChain have a perverse incentive that results in witches casting ever worse curses in order to profit? Yes.

What happens when the underlying deep-magick is broken? Recent developments in so-called "post-quantum magick" are promising, and we are building magick-agility into our platform to ensure we can take advantage of newer hashed-quark-based spellcasting.

Can curses with large/complicated definitions be stored off chain via true name pointers? For now, complicated curses require sub-curses/ multiple blocks. The community is currently rationally discussing the merits of offchain storage via reddit & memes.

Upgrading curses across æons has traditionally involved burdensome translations and pentagram activations. Inter-æon upgrades are a thing of the past thanks to our lisp-oriented smart-curses language and the same magick which keeps COBOL alive.

Curses cursing CurseChain cause canceled curses conclusively ceasing curses causing CurseChain cursedness, consequently countermanding CurseChain's curse.

Alena Vranova was a member of the founding team at both the bitcoin custody solutions startup Casa and the hardware wallet company SatoshiLabs. She discovered bitcoin in 2010. Her passion for censorship-resistant technology and financial sovereignty comes from her family’s own experience with the Czech Republic’s former authoritarian regime.

Why I Love Bitcoin

This little secret has been traveling with me throughout time: I smile, but I don’t listen to naysayers.

Mostly, people told me my plans were never going to work. With the hardware wallet company, it was a huge responsibility and a risk. We were accepting people’s money for research and development and we weren’t sure it was going to work. But we did it. People at the banks also said I was crazy. Yet we built SatoshiLabs.

People ask me a lot about what it is like being a woman in bitcoin. I don’t know. It’s the same as being anywhere else. I believe women are equal, but behaving equal and the same as men would be extremely boring. I am a big believer in voluntarism, i.e. consent.

With bitcoin, you opt in or opt out, no one is forcing you to use bitcoin. Consent with bitcoin is something different than the norm with fiat currencies—you cannot decline the state-issued currency. I love freedom. And I see bitcoin as a tool that can be used for the expression of personal freedom.

Bitcoin 101

Beyond the price hype, there is a computing revolution. Yes, there’s a lot of talk about price and criminal activity. But it’s far more important to consider what bitcoin can do in terms of our privacy and experience of online shopping.

In the 1960s, IBM was among the companies building the first computers. These computers were basically for local computing, mainframe computers running local apps. Eventually, Apple revolutionized this approach and brought personalized computing with local apps. Now, with the mass adoption of the internet, we started to develop more computationally heavy applications and we’ve graduated to the third wave of computing: the Cloud.

These server houses are running network apps and our phones are called slave devices because they rely on these servers running local apps. Now we have these huge honeypots of data in “the Cloud” that are vulnerable online.

What bitcoin created was, basically, a way for us to take back the data. And bitcoin works at its best when you yourself hold your private keys.

Bad things happen when you give those keys away. And you learn from that. You take back the important data and encrypt it by default. We can make our systems much more resilient and safe for the future that’s coming. We need—as individuals and as companies—to build tools that help protect us.

This is what we call the fourth wave of computing. Bitcoin started this fourth wave. We can have home computing running decentralized apps. Before, we had local computing or network computing. We’re still using cloud computing today, with local apps. What we learn from bitcoin is that we can rebuild the ecosystem.

Second-wave cypherpunks

As a teenager, I had a personal revolution, as so many of us do. I saw myself as an anarchist and a punk. Later in life, it became clear in practice that the political system was not built well. This is why bitcoin is so fascinating to me: It takes back the power.

I’m not a coder, but I’m a cypherpunk at heart. We could see another wave of the cypherpunk movement, through bitcoin, if we see tools that make it easier for people to do encryption.

With a bitcoin wallet, you create the backup at the beginning and thanks to the open nature of the blockchain that is publicly listed, you could go to that first initial backup and recover all the data. If we apply that in a user-friendly way, we could also apply that to document storage and data management.

Bitcoin could be the future’s global reserve, held by people and not banks. We’re definitely working to scale the network so that we can also use this as a payment system. Will it work in both ways, both as a reserve and for payments? I don’t know. But it’s interesting to imagine you could fundamentally redesign and rebuild the applications we have today with micropayments. I could have a decentralized storage for documents, for example.

I really like to dream ahead. Sometimes, I’m way ahead. Ha!

Emily Faria is a 27-year-old engineer from Venezuela, currently getting a master’s degree in environmental engineering. She found bitcoin in the summer of 2017, working at CriptoNoticias, a news site in Spanish specializing in bitcoin, cryptocurrencies, and blockchain technology, as a way to earn income during the economic crisis. She currently works for another news site as well, called Bitcoin.es.

A Bit of Freedom

Serendipity is a fortunate, valuable, and unexpected finding that occurs accidentally or casually. It’s something amazing that you find when you are probably looking for another thing.

For me, meeting bitcoin has been all about serendipity.

As I write this on September 29th, 2019, bitcoin’s price hovers around $8,100, marking a nearly 20 percent dip over the past few days. Am I worried about that?

No.

Such volatility represents just another episode in bitcoin’s history. I understand the value of bitcoin is more than its price. It’s actually about freedom.

Bitcoin, a peer-to-peer electronic cash system, a decade-old experiment with some disadvantages, can take power from governments and give it back to the people. (This is the most important reason why some governments reject bitcoin). This system has been the best tool for circumnavigating the government’s control of financial institutions that I’ve ever known.

And you may not know how much that means to me, living in a country like Venezuela.

Bitcoiner lifestyle

My country is in crisis, with a dictatorial government, rampant censorship, strict capital controls, and frequent blackouts. Here, I have experienced banking restrictions, money control, cash prohibition, and unlimited issuance of money, which has lost its value. Here, banks decide how much money can be withdrawn in cash or how much can be spent through debit cards on a daily basis. The money is yours, but the central banks decide for you.

Looking for a job online, I became immersed in the world of cryptocurrencies around 2017. That opened a door toward a new universe for me. I write articles about Bitcoin, crypto assets, and blockchain technology, and I have received my payment for this work in bitcoin.

My current boss, who lives in Europe, sends the payments directly to my wallet. It only takes about 10 minutes. The process is done without third parties, authorities, banks, or taxes; only wallets. Also, the network allows the person who sends the bitcoin to decide the fees, based on if it needs to be done quickly or whether the transaction can wait.

In addition, my family uses bitcoin for remittances. My sister lives in another Latin American country and sends money back to the family using bitcoin. I exchange them on the ground for Venezuelan currency (bolívares) or US dollars as needed.

I do not use bitcoin as a speculative tool. Every week, I sell satoshis to buy food and things that my family and I need. Also, I pay the rent, my master’s degree tuition, and course registration with the bolívares that I receive for my satoshis. My economy is based on bitcoin even though the adoption in Venezuela has been slow (I only know of one place in my city that accepts bitcoin as a payment method).

Bitcoin works

From my experience, I can say bitcoin works as real money, and it is a global currency without borders or censorship. In addition to using bitcoin for payments, you may also use it to store long-term value. But you need to keep in mind that it’s still an experiment, so if you want to invest in bitcoin, you have to accept the risks. In my case, it isn’t easy being a “hodler”, but I try my best.

Here in Venezuela, I prefer to trade among friends and via peer-to-peer exchanges. I don’t really like exchanges that ask for personal information and documents to sign (even though I've sometimes had to use them to get bolívares).

If any service asks for that kind of data, you are using a service you are trusting with your money; such service could also give that information to governments, be a victim of hackers, or actually ban your account, like traditional companies that provide online money transfer and digital payment services. And bitcoin is trying to be a way to eliminate all that.

Whenever I must use a centralized exchange, I don't link my bank accounts with my bitcoin wallets. I’m really careful with my addresses and my identity.

Bitcoin is a tool that lets you to separate financial transactions from identity; it isn’t anonymous, because everybody can see the transactions; however, no one can see the reason and the identity of the persons related to the transaction; but bad people could find ways to connect both things, so you need good practices to protect your privacy.

With Bitcoin, I’ve chosen to exercise my human right to liberty and private property, even in the middle of a dictatorial government. I decide for myself how much and when to send or receive money.

Bitcoin is more than money

It’s exciting to see so many people around the world working on the continuous improvement and growth of Bitcoin. It’s like a kind of brotherhood, including anonymous contributors, with different nationalities, languages, etc., connected by the same objective: financial freedom. At this point, I would like to add that I have met incredible people thanks to Bitcoin.

It may seem complicated when you first hear about bitcoin. But it’s actually easy to transact with it and you don't have to be an expert to use bitcoin. There are more tools and proposals to improve the Bitcoin network every day, something new to learn about this system. However, I think the most important thing is to learn about the values behind this project.

Bitcoin’s contribution to the digital society is enormous: to eliminate trust in third parties, which have become practically indispensable for making electronic payments—a trust based on our sharing our identity, exposing our financial data to hackers, and empowering authorities and companies over our money.

Since I think bitcoin is helping to create a new global economy, I don’t want to be left out. I assume the risks of using bitcoin. Even if bitcoin fails (personally, I think that won’t happen), I won’t regret believing in this project and being part of this community. At least we are trying to be free and take control of our money and destinies.

I found bitcoin to deal with a terrible situation and it’s been one of the best things that I’ve known. Yet, like stars, this technology shines brightest during this dark period in Venezuela.

Using bitcoin has given me a little bit more freedom.

BitcoinStripper is a sex worker who fell in love with bitcoin while searching for an internationally accessible electronic payment system that would allow clients to make instant payments without either parties revealing personally identifying data. Experience indicated the solution had to prevent chargebacks or transaction cancellations as well. Once she realized the potential of bitcoin for sex workers, she became a relentless evangelist, teaching her clients and other sex workers about the advantages of transacting in bitcoin.

How Do I Love B? Let Me Count the Ways

I’ve loved B for a long time now
Such a gift B did endow
I love B… privacy incomplete
Best practices make more discreet
I love B though you’re experimental
B is the king! Avoid shitcoins like denta…
B has low transaction fees
B’s ease of use became a breeze
I love B. You’re permissionless
And that removes financial stress
I love B through the China bans
Through bulls and bears and forking plans
I love B every time B dies
Because B is decentralized

Chrissa McFarlane is the CEO of the blockchain startup Patientory, which helped distribute diagnostic kits and medical equipment during the COVID-19 crisis. She first learned about bitcoin in 2010, started working on broader blockchain solutions in 2015, and later published the nonfiction book Future Women: Minority Female Entrepreneurship and the Fourth Industrial Revolution in the Era of Blockchain and Cryptocurrency. (Leigh Cuen also contributed to this glossary.)

Glossary

Cryptocurrency: Currency that uses cryptography, which is the art of coding messages to keep them secure. Most types of money, like dollars, are already digital. We use digital currency when we shop online or send money with apps like Venmo. For cryptocurrency, the system’s underlying security model is the differentiating factor. Most cryptocurrencies are supposed to be decentralized or are relatively so, even if they fall short of bitcoin’s diversity.

Decentralization: When data and tasks are spread across a network instead of coming from a central source, like a bank or treasury. For example, there is no bitcoin company or bitcoin overlord in charge of bitcoin transactions. Community members contribute computing power to fuel the bitcoin network. Transaction records are spread across the network.

Bitcoin: Bitcoin was the first cryptocurrency. It uses blockchain technology, a type of software that spreads data out across the network of participants so no single party can change the records. In bitcoin’s case, the receipts for every transaction are public. They are associated with bitcoin wallet addresses, comparable to email addresses except they are longer and harder to memorize. Bitcoin is the most secure cryptocurrency because, so far, it has the most people contributing to the network. Cryptocurrencies often rely on the “safety in numbers” principle.

Mining: The process of making new bitcoin. People run specialized computers that can calculate very difficult math problems in order to verify bitcoin transactions and write them into the shared ledger. In bitcoin’s case, this is called “proof of work,” referring to the complex math problems that require lots of power and specialized hardware.

Halving: Bitcoin software was designed so it gets harder to “mine” new bitcoin as time goes on. The software automatically slashes returns every few years, that slash is called the “halving.”

Ledger: A file or receipt for recording transactions and changes to an account balance. “Ledger” shouldn’t be confused with trade history, as the ledger balance can provide more information like balances on a specific date, margin trades, or what a currency was traded for, depending on the type of ledger.

Hedge: The saying goes “don’t put all your eggs in one basket.” That’s basically what hedging means. Some people reduce risk investment by using financial instruments like futures contracts, legal agreements to buy or sell an asset at a predetermined price at a specified time in the future. In trading, hedging strategies are often used to offset the risk of drastic price changes, especially in volatile cryptocurrency markets.

Capital markets: The broad spectrum of tradable assets which includes the stock market and the cryptocurrency market. Government bonds are another example.

Settlement costs: The average price at which a cryptocurrency trades. The “taker” pays a fee while the “maker” receives a rebate once there is a match. Then the trade is settled automatically on an exchange platform. This same concept applies to capital markets. Any time there’s a middleman involved in a transaction, there are extra fees.

Node: All software is connected to hardware, somewhere, and likewise a bitcoin node supports the network by validating transactions. Some people download node software on their own laptops, some build node devices using a Raspberry Pi. Either way, the node is what gives the user their own full copy of the blockchain, rather than relying on other people’s hardware to keep track of the public ledger.

Fiat (vs. just currency): Fiat currency is a government-issued instrument of value, a.k.a money associated with a nation-state, like dollars. This money is no longer backed by commodities or precious metals, like gold or silver. Its value comes from the fact that people trust that government. Other types of currency are often backed by commodities.

Hodl/hodler: Hodling means saving cryptocurrency for an extended period of time, as opposed to selling when the fiat-denominated price of cryptocurrency fluctuates. A hodler is someone that saves or holds cryptocurrency for many years.

Liquidity: How useful is this money? US dollars are highly liquid, you can spend them quickly in most circumstances. Some assets traded on capital markets are less liquid, meaning there’s more paperwork or restrictions in spending them. Another limitation is how hard it is to money at-scale, like physical gold. As such, liquidity in the market means how easily money can move or be used without disrupting a system.

Exchanges: Businesses that sell assets or allow people to trade assets. There are stock exchanges and currency exchanges. Cryptocurrency exchanges are businesses too, providing online places for people to trade or buy assets like bitcoin.

Recovery seed: A seed recovery phrase or backup seed phrase is a list of words that act as a collective password. Wallet software will typically generate a seed phrase and instruct the user to write it down on paper. Then, if something happens to that specific wallet device, the user can still recover access to the funds another way.

Bear market vs. bull market: In short, a bear market means the numbers go down while in a bull market they trend up. Generally speaking, in a bear market, prices are low, demand may be low, and liquidity is lower than usual. On the other hand, in a bull market, everyone wants the asset. For example, 2017 was a year of bull markets in the cryptocurrency space. The price of bitcoin skyrocketed, people were actively trading and buying, venture capitalists were investing in cryptocurrency projects, etc. Money flows quickly and easily. So people can say “bearish” to mean they are pessimistic about something and “bullish” to mean optimistic about it.

Permissioned vs. public network: The internet is quite literally a web of connected networks. Some of them are public, meaning anyone with the right hardware can access it. Some networks, like at a hospital or bank, are private. Often called “permissioned,” this means a computer needs permission to access that data or site. All the software in the world is information inside a piece of hardware, somewhere. When we sign in to a private network, say by working from home, it’s noticeable that we are asking computers to bounce messages asking each other for the information, relayed from the employer’s private network back to our devices at home. In a public network, computers are still playing that game of telephone on our behalf across networks, just without gatekeepers. The bitcoin network is public, meaning anyone who knows how can get data from the circulating flow.

Sats/Satoshis: Tiny fractions of bitcoin. Sats, short for “Satoshis” after bitcoin creator Satoshi Nakamoto, are to bitcoin what cents are to dollars.

Lightning Network: This scaling solution that adds an upper layer to bitcoin, so to speak, for transactions to move around faster and cheaper without waiting in line at the blockchain base layer. The internet is built in layers. Software is just code that triggers on or off, ones or zeroes, like flicking a light switch. There's electricity and machines that trigger a chain reaction, carrying power from a distant source to your lamp. Removing any part of this system would mean the bulb doesn't light. Likewise, people refer to the Lightning Network as a scaling system “on top of” bitcoin, which is the base layer, because it is a complementary system. People can use the Lightning Network if they don’t need to spend the time and (higher) transaction fees required for a simple bitcoin transaction, which offers more security than this complementary network, Lightning. Data and messages can be passed around in many ways that still result in a bitcoin transaction. People usually send smaller amounts of bitcoin on Lightning, which they call Satoshis.
